hints.content: Start by parsing the input date string. You can use string manipulation to extract the year, month, and day. For example, you might split the string by the '-' character.
Remember that months have different numbers of days. Create a list or dictionary that maps each month to its corresponding number of days. Don't forget about February, especially in leap years!

Consider how to handle the transition from the last day of a month to the first day of the next month. For instance, if the current day is the last day of the month, you will need to reset the day to 1 and increment the month.
Leap years occur every 4 years, but not every year divisible by 100 is a leap year unless it is also divisible by 400. Make sure to implement a function to check if a year is a leap year.
When incrementing the month, be cautious about what happens when you reach December. You will need to reset the month to January and increment the year.
After incrementing the day, check if it exceeds the number of days in the current month. If it does, reset the day and increment the month.
If you find yourself needing to increment the month, check if it goes beyond 12. If it does, reset the month to 1 and increment the year.
Make sure to format the output correctly. The output should be in the same 'YYYY-MM-DD' format as the input. You might want to use string formatting to ensure leading zeros are preserved.
Consider edge cases, such as the transition from December 31 to January 1 of the next year. This will require careful handling of both month and year increments.
Finally, put all the pieces together. After parsing the date, handle the day increment, check for month overflow, and finally check for year overflow. Return the formatted date string as the result.

questionNotes: Handle month and year transitions carefully.
